text:
When you picture the four seasons - assuming
you live in a place where four seasons are

a thing - you probably think of summer and
winter as opposites - after all, one is hot

and one is cold - and the rest of the year
as this middle ground we travel back and forth

through on our way from one extreme to another...in
other words, fall seems like spring in reverse.

But the reality, at least based on how we
technically define seasons, is totally different.

Because the astronomical system, which we
four-season folk use for most things, defines
seasons not via temperature, but via daylight.

Over the course of a year, the amount of daylight
you experience on a given day oscillates in
what’s basically a sine wave.

This is how the hours of daylight change across
the course of a year in the northern hemisphere.

The places where the wave crosses this line
are “equinoxes” - days with nearly equal

hours of daylight and darkness - and the peaks
are “solstices” - the days with the most

and least daylight; these features are how
we technically divvy up the seasons.

And when you look at the seasons like this,
you can see that it’s actually summer that’s

spring in reverse - not fall; during spring,
we go from equal hours of day and darkness

to peak daylight, and over the course of summer,
we go right back to equal hours of day and

darkness, where we had started at the beginning
of spring.

The same pattern - but inverted - occurs later
in the year; winter is actually fall happening
in reverse.

But as clear as that is on the graph, it doesn’t
make any sense as far as how we actually experience

the seasons; winter doesn’t feel anything
like fall happening in reverse.

And if spring and summer have the same amount
of daylight overall, why is summer so much
hotter?

Well, just like it takes a while for a pot
of water to boil on a stove, it takes a while

for changing daylight patterns to have an
effect on temperature.

Daylight increases over the course of spring,
but since Earth’s temperature rises slowly

in response, we generally don’t have our
hottest days until the amount of daylight
has already started to decrease.

And since the falling temperature lags behind
the decreasing daylight, the coldest days

tend to happen once daylight has already started
increasing.

Looking at the temperature graph, spring and
fall are reverse versions of the same middle

ground - and everything we experience about
seasons makes sense.

So why don’t we just use temperature to
divide up the four seasons?

Well, compared to temperature, which can vary
wildly from year to year, daylight is simply
more consistent.

Daylight is so predictable that we’ve relied
on it for thousands of years to mark the passage

of time and track annual events, like the
flooding of rivers and the best time to plant
seeds.

That deep-seed-ed relationship with daylight
is probably why it came to dictate the transitions

between our four modern seasons, even if these
days, it’s temperature - rather than daylight
- that puts a spring in our step.

Given that - at least for those of us in the
northern hemisphere - our days are getting

shorter and our temps are getting colder,
you might be looking to learn about the world
in a cozy, indoor, kind of way.
